did.abstract: Outdoor writer and photographer for The Ann Arbor News, advocate of environment issues, author of local interest and music review columns; articles written and photographs taken by Fulton, personal correspondence and documentation of awards received.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers were donated in 2008 by Anna Summers Fulton (donor number 8576). The bulk of the materials came to the library in 2008; with additional accession in 2013. Previous materials were received in 1997 and 1999.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Douglas Fulton papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Douglas Fulton (1928-1996) was an award-winning outdoor writer and photographer for The Ann Arbor News. He was also a well-known conservationist who worked with various state and local committees, advisory boards, and advocacy groups.

Fulton was born in Illinois and raised in Arizona. He earned a B.A. in languages from the University of Arizona in 1949 and his M.A. in linguistics from the University of Michigan in 1951. Fulton began his career as a photographer with the Air Force; he served for four years in the early 1950s during the Korean War. He was first hired by The Ann Arbor News as a temporary photographer in the late 1950s. He found that he liked journalism and remained with the paper for the duration of his career. In1962, he began writing "A Naturalist's Journal," a weekly column which lasted until his retirement in 1983. In 1968, he was appointed Outdoor Editor and in the following years he expanded the length and scope of this section of the paper. He also wrote a music column for about five years during the 1970s. Due to health problems, Fulton retired early in 1983. He received many awards throughout his career for both his writing and photography. Among those organizations that honored him were the Associated Press, National Press Photographers Association, Outdoor Writers Association of America, and Michigan Outdoor Writers Association.

In his personal life, Fulton worked in various capacities to advocate for the environment. He participated in efforts to create and protect local and state park lands and encouraged low-impact development and helped promote environmental education. Locally, he worked to protect natural areas such as Gallup Park. On the state level, he was instrumental in establishing federal protection for natural areas such as Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore and Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore. He also helped to author the Michigan Wilderness Act. The most notable recognition for his advocacy efforts may have been the Conservation Communicator of the Year award which he received from the Michigan United Conservation Clubs in 1970.

scopecontent.p: This collection documents Doug Fulton's career as a journalist and photographer for The Ann Arbor News. Personal correspondence and clippings are also included. The collection is divided into four series: Articles, Personal, Visual Materials, and Subject Files.

The Articles series (6 linear feet) consists of various articles and photographic pieces that Fulton produced for The Ann Arbor News. These articles feature Fulton's work for several different sections of the paper including Connection (a local interest section), the Outdoor Pages, live music and record review columns, and the Photo Pages of the paper. The bulk of Fulton's work was for the Outdoor and Photo Pages. His work on the Outdoor Pages had a national scope and included purely recreational stories as well as those strongly motivated by his conservationist views. His work on the Photo Pages also covered a wide range of topics. A set of correspondence related to Fulton's work is also included in this series; a significant amount of letters in praise of Fulton's articles and photographs are included here.

did.unittitle: The Ann Arbor News Township Series 1956

scopecontent.p: The Personal (2 linear feet) series includes coverage of the journalism and conservation awards that Fulton received throughout his career. Also included, is correspondence relating to environmental issues and other personal pursuits.

did.unittitle: Letter to President Reagan Regarding Doug Fulton
A Desert Scrapbook (newsletter authored by Doug and Anna Fulton)
Photographs and Portraits of Doug Fulton

scopecontent.p: The Visual Materials (2 linear feet) series includes photographic prints and negatives associated with the stories Fulton worked on throughout his career. As mentioned above, these covered a range of subjects including recreational and conservationist topics, local and national subjects. Also included here are photographs Fulton did for advertisements. Negatives on the subject of nature include aerial images, images of plants, animals, recreational activities, and images taken by Fulton during his trips around Michigan, the U.S. and Canada. Some negatives in this subject group are accompanied by newspaper articles in which images have appeared. The Dance and Theater negatives include images of performances and concerts, mostly dance. Of note are images of Merce Cunningham, Gertrude Prokosch Kurath, José Limón, Louis Mekush, and Elizabeth Weil Bergmann. Also included here is a group of negatives titled Blues Photo Collection with images (and some photographs) of blues musicians. Most of the images in this group were taken during the Ann Arbor Blues and Jazz Festivals

Ann Arbor Blues and Jazz Festival 1972

scopecontent.p: The Subject Files (1 linear foot) series consists of material that Fulton amassed for research purposes. Anti-hunt opinions receive significant coverage and some local issues are also documented. Other wildlife writers and artists, including Bil Gilbert, are also documented within this series.
